Hearing.intro: <info>[House Hearing, 115 Congress]</info> <info>[From the U.S. Government Publishing Office]</info> <Doc-title>REQUESTING THE PRESIDENT, AND DIRECTING THE SECRETARY OF STATE, TO TRANSMIT TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES COPIES OF ALL DOCUMENTS, RECORDS, COMMUNICATIONS, TRANSCRIPTS, SUMMARIES, NOTES, MEMORANDA, AND READ-AHEADS IN THEIR POSSESSION REFERRING TO CERTAIN COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP AND PRESIDENT VLADIMIR PUTIN</Doc-title> <option> TRANSMIT TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES COPIES OF ALL DOCUMENTS, RECORDS, COMMUNICATIONS, TRANSCRIPTS, SUMMARIES, NOTES, MEMORANDA, AND READ-AHEADS IN THEIR POSSESSION REFERRING TO CERTAIN COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP AND PRESIDENT VLADIMIR PUTIN ======================================================================= MARKUP BEFORE THE </option> <committee_name>COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS</committee_name> <option> HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES ONE HUNDRED FIFTEENTH CONGRESS SECOND SESSION ON H. Res. 1017 __________ SEPTEMBER 13, 2018 __________ Serial No. 115-157 __________ Printed for the use of the Committee on Foreign Affairs Available: http://www.foreignaffairs.house.gov/, http://docs.house.gov, or http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/ ______ U.S. GOVERNMENT PUBLISHING OFFICE 31-454PDF WASHINGTON : 2018 </option>

Hearing.Directory: <table-of-content>C O N T E N T S</table-of-content> <peopleSpeaker> H Res </peopleSpeaker> <peopleinfo>Requesting the President and directing the Secretary of State to transmit to the House of Representatives copies of all documents</peopleinfo> <option>APPENDIX</option> <option>Markup notice.................................................... 20 Markup minutes................................................... 21 Markup summary and record vote description....................... 23 The Honorable Gerald E. Connolly, a Representative in Congress from the Commonwealth of Virginia: Material submitted for the record.............................. 24 Prepared statement............................................. 28 </option> <Doc-title>REQUESTING THE PRESIDENT, AND DIRECTING THE SECRETARY OF STATE, TO TRANSMIT TO THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES COPIES OF ALL DOCUMENTS, RECORDS, COMMUNICATIONS, TRANSCRIPTS, SUMMARIES, NOTES, MEMORANDA, AND READ-AHEADS IN THEIR POSSESSION REFERRING TO CERTAIN COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP AND PRESIDENT VLADIMIR PUTIN</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="">THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 2018</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="">House of Representatives,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="">Committee on Foreign Affairs,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="">Washington, DC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 12:30 p.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">The committee will come to order.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>[The information referred to follows:]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker=""> We meet today to consider a single item. Pursuant to notice, for purposes of markup, I call up House Resolution 1017, requesting the President, and directing the Secretary of State, to transmit to the House copies of all documents in their possession relating to certain communications between President Trump and Russian President Putin and move to report it adversely to the House. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Royce">Without objection, the resolution is considered read and open for amendment at any point, and committee members may have 5 calendar days to submit statements for the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">Because we are dealing with floor votes, activities of other committees, and hurricane-related uncertainty this afternoon, I am going to use my vote postponement authority under committee rules to ensure that all members are given fair notice to participate in any recorded vote we may have.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">And I now recognize myself for opening remarks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">This afternoon, we meet to consider House Resolution 1017. As members know, we typically want to see extensive bipartisan consultation and at least 25 co-sponsors before marking up resolutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">This measure does not fall into that category. It was introduced with no committee consultation and no co-sponsors, as we enter the final stretch of an election campaign.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">And we are here today only because it enjoys privilege under House rules as a ``resolution of inquiry,'' which we have a duty to report.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">Because this resolution clearly intrudes into judicially recognized areas of executive privilege and would likely require years of contested and, ultimately, fruitless litigation, we should not endorse it. Let me explain.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">This resolution would set a dangerous and harmful precedent with respect to Presidential communications. It demands from the President every document, communication, transcript, summary, note, or memo that relates to matters proposed or discussed or agreed to or otherwise covered during, in connection with, or in preparation for his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Helsinki back in July.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">Let me be clear. I strongly disagreed with the President's remarks in Helsinki. Vladimir Putin is not our friend, and there is simply no comparing the actions of the United States with those of Putin's Russia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">Ultimately, Helsinki was a squandered opportunity to challenge Vladimir Putin's false narratives on issues including Ukraine and Syria and Russia's ongoing interference in our democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">So I understand the interest in these issues. I'm sure this resolution is a popular idea in some political circles.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">But, ultimately, it is not a wise approach to oversight. Indeed, it would only threaten to distract from the bipartisan legislative and investigative efforts of this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">This resolution's broad demand for documents conflicts with the strongest form of executive privilege recognized by the courts--the so-called Presidential communications privilege.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">Rooted in the constitutional separation of powers, Presidential communications privilege applies to direct decision making by the President and also protects communications made or solicited or received by his advisors while preparing advice for him.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">These privileges are at their strongest when they deal with the President's core constitutional powers, such as his authority to conduct diplomatic discussions with foreign leaders, and this is with good cause.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">Today we have instant communications, but Presidents still have and need the authority to meet and speak and negotiate privately with foreign leaders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce">Consider the historic Camp David Accords, a diplomatic triumph that strengthened our national security. Members will recall this agreement was preceded by 2 weeks of confidential negotiations among the American, Israeli, and Egyptian heads of state, sequestered in the woods of Maryland.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Royce">And during that time, some were genuinely concerned that Jimmy Carter might undermine the security of our ally, Israel. Yet, Congress wasn't privy to every utterance.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Royce">By constitutional design, we are not in the room for such discussions. We didn't demand transcripts of every conversation President Obama had with the Russians, even after an open microphone caught him asking President Medvedev for some ``space'' on missile defense issues, explaining that we would ``have more flexibility'' after his November 2012 reelection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Royce">This resolution before us today has implications far beyond our current President or our last President. It is about the ability of all Presidents to engage with foreign leaders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Royce">And, sadly, this resolution goes against the grain of this committee's important bipartisan work to confront Russia's dangerous acts.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Royce">As my colleagues know, this includes powerful sanctions, which we authored, on Russian hackers and intelligence agencies, passed as part of the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act, which the administration needs to better utilize.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Royce">It includes additional sanctions to punish Russia for propping up the murderous Assad regime in Syria, which the Senate needs to pass on to the President's desk without further delay; and successfully pushing for the imposition of new mandatory Russian sanctions under the Chemical and Biological Weapons and Warfare Elimination Act, following Russia's use of military-grade chemical weapons to poison British citizen Sergei Skripal and his daughter on British soil.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Royce">It includes creating a strong reformed export controls process that will better protect U.S. advances in emerging technology like robotics and artificial intelligence, and legislatively authorizing the President to provide defensive military systems to Ukraine and to strengthen its cyber defenses against Russian attacks; reforming the Broadcasting Board of Governors to help revitalize U.S. efforts to counter Russian propaganda and disinformation; and enacting the Global Magnitsky Human Rights Accountability Act--named after a Russian businessman who was murdered by corrupt Russian authorities--to hold regimes accountable for human rights abuses; and it includes passing through the full House just last week the Cyber Deterrence and Response Act, to name, shame, and sanction foreign actors who carry out cyber attacks against the United States.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have taken these actions together because most of us have been concerned about administration policies toward Russia. I certainly have been.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Royce"> So I intend for the committee to continue to pursue its serious, bipartisan, and consequential oversight. But for the reasons I have laid out, I cannot support this resolution and I urge my colleagues to join me in reporting it adversely to the House. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman, and as I've said many, many times privately and publicly, I want to thank you for the fair way you've always run this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">I know this is an unusual situation for both of us. But we have reached the point with this administration when I believe it's time for tougher action to be taken.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">For 18 months we have been trying to exercise basic oversight of the State Department. Two Secretaries of State have been here and have said they'd be responsive to our committee's requests. It hasn't happened.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">We have been stonewalled over and over again. We have heard excuse after excuse after excuse, and on the rare occasion like today that the administration sends officials to testify before our committee, we rarely get the answers we need.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">This has frustrated me and I've heard the same from many of our members, and the secret meeting between President Trump and President Putin in Helsinki was the last straw, literally.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">Vladimir Putin unleashed an attack on our democracy to try to get Donald Trump elected. President Trump cozies up to Putin at every turn. He sides with Putin over our own intelligence community.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">So when they went into a room together--no staff, no advisors, just the two of them, and interpreters--alarm bells went off all over Washington, DC, and around the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">It was unprecedented under any circumstances and particularly troubling in light of the Trump-Russia scandal swirling around this President and his administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">As Special Counsel Mueller continues to rack up indictments and convictions, my concern is only growing. Now 2 months later, the alarm is still going off because the American people still have no idea what was discussed in that meeting between Putin and Trump.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">We need to know. This is a matter of national security, and when an administration--and this would go for any administration of either party--shows such bizarre deference to an adversary who, clearly, means us harm, it falls to Congress to get the answers. That's our job.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">Mr. Chairman, I know you've been working hard to get Secretary Pompeo in front of our committee so we can all ask these questions. It's outrageous that he hasn't come before us, especially since he did pay the Senate that courtesy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel">But you have tried to allow us to do our job and I am grateful for your effort. This administration just doesn't seem to respect Congress' role as a co-equal branch of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Mr. Engel">So we are running out of options. The resolution that Mr. Boyle has introduced represents one of the few tools Congress has in its rules to get answers from an administration.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Mr. Engel">I share the frustration that led Mr. Boyle to offer this measure and I fully support his effort to find out what happened in President Trump's failed summit with the Russian dictator in Helsinki.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Mr. Engel">I think it's a pretty reasonable set of requests. I wish it weren't necessary. I wish the State Department would do what Secretaries Tillerson and Pompeo promised, which is to respond to our document requests and heed our efforts to carry out Congress' constitutional responsibilities by conducting basic oversight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Mr. Engel">But they have not, and we need to face facts. The Trump administration is not going to give us the information we need willingly. Congress has requested. They've said no.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Mr. Engel">What we are left with is for Congress to demand, and because that's the only option left for Congress to demand, we are also left with only one question--what will Congress decide to do?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Mr. Engel">We are not the first committee to take up a resolution like this since the start of the Trump presidency. In other cases, markups have descended into partisan rancor.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Mr. Engel">Certainly they haven't resulted in getting any information from the executive branch. In my view, the Republican leadership in the House has opted to cover for this administration rather than allowing this body to do its job and exercise our checks and balances.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Mr. Engel">I am confident, based on this committee's culture, under your leadership, Mr. Chairman, that this markup won't follow that path. In fact, I hope we can have a good debate about Mr. Boyle's resolution, because if anyone thinks we and the American people shouldn't know what happened in that meeting, I'd like to hear why and I'd like to hear that debate continue on the House floor.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Mr. Engel">As I said, the only question left is, what will Congress decide to do? It should be up to the entire House to weigh in on that decision. We shouldn't end this debate here. We shouldn't end it today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="50" speaker="Mr. Engel">And so, Mr. Chairman, respectfully, I must oppose your motion and if it's voted down I'll offer a motion of my own to report this resolution favorably, designating Mr. Boyle of Pennsylvania to call it up for consideration by the House.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="51" speaker="Mr. Engel"> Again, Mr. Chairman, as I have said many times publicly and privately I am grateful to you for your fairness and leadership, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="52" speaker="Chairman Royce">The gentleman yields back.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="53" speaker="Chairman Royce">Floor votes are now underway. We have 4 minutes left in the vote. We will recess and then resume our markup immediately after the final vote in this two-vote series.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="54" speaker="Chairman Royce">So I urge members to return promptly after casting the second vote. We stand in recess.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="55" speaker="Chairman Royce"> [Recess.] </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="56" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Mr. Sires. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Sires</speaker> <paragraph paraId="57" speaker="Mr. Sires">Mr. Chairman, thank you very much.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="58" speaker="Mr. Sires">The reason--where am I? My reason here, Chairman--the reason we are here today is simple. President Trump stood next to Vladimir Putin and took his side over the American people and our intelligence community.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="59" speaker="Mr. Sires">He let Putin lie and say Russia did not have--did not hack our elections. In my eyes, he stood on stage with Putin and failed to defend someone who is committed to destroying this country.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="60" speaker="Mr. Sires">He took a private meeting with Putin with no aides present. We still don't know what happened in that meeting. The American people deserve to know what our President said to one of our adversaries.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="61" speaker="Mr. Sires">It is unacceptable that the administration continues to cozy up to the Russians at the expense of our security and safety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="62" speaker="Mr. Sires">We were sent here to conduct oversight of the administration's policies and we deserve to know what the President and Putin discussed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="63" speaker="Mr. Sires"> Thank you, Mr. Chairman. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="64" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="65" speaker="Chairman Royce">Any other members seek recognition?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="66" speaker="Chairman Royce">Any other members seek recognition to speak?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="67" speaker="Chairman Royce">[Pause.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="68" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Do any members seek recognition? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Cicilline</speaker> <paragraph paraId="69" speaker="Mr. Cicilline"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Cicilline</speaker> <paragraph paraId="70" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Yes. Move to strike the last word.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="71" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Mr. Chairman, I support House Resolution 1017, which requests that the administration turn over documents related to the July 16th meeting between Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="72" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Two months after the fact, Congress and the American people still know nothing or next to nothing about what was discussed between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin in a private 2-hour meeting in which none of the President's advisors were present.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="73" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">After that meeting, President Trump stood on a stage with Vladimir Putin, a man who directed his military to launch a cyber attack on our country's elections and whose regime regularly has journalists murdered, LGBT individuals tortured, and political opponents thrown into jail.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="74" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Rather than standing up to President Putin, President Trump bent over backwards to appease a dictator and even defended Putin while denigrating our FBI, our intelligence officials, and anyone who wants to see Putin held accountable for his actions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="75" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">This was an incredibly embarrassing and sad day for America. Based on the President's own words, here's what we know about what took place in the meeting.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="76" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">The two had, I quote, ``a direct, open, deeply productive dialogue and spoke on a wide range of critical issues for both of our countries.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="77" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">The President believed Putin when he told him that it was not Russia that interfered in the 2016 elections, regardless of the fact that the U.S. intelligence community has without a doubt identified Russia as the source of the attack.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="78" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">He has since walked back the stance after widespread outrage and the mountains of clear evidence to the contrary of his claims.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="79" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">The President also apparently considered Putin's incredible offer, as he called it, to allow Russians to question Ambassadors and employees of the United States intelligence community. He walked this back too after even his own advisors were incredulous at this absolutely nonsensical and dangerous proposal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="80" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Substantively, most of what we know about the meeting has come from the Russian Government. A Russian major general was reported to have said that the Russian ministry of defense is ready for practical implementation of international security agreements reached between Russian President Vladimir Putin and U.S. President Donald Trump at the Helsinki Summit.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="81" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Despite this committee's repeated requests, the administration still hasn't told the American people or this committee anything substantive about the meeting in Helsinki and certainly nothing about these alleged international security agreements.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="82" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">This committee has the constitutional authority and responsibility to conduct oversight and get answers. The administration's lack of transparency about what was said and agreed to is particularly disturbing in light of the ongoing investigation into the Trump campaign's ties to Russia, which has so far produced nearly 200 criminal charges and active indictments or to which individuals have already pled guilty.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="83" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Vladimir Putin is not a friend of the United States or the American people. He's a brutal dictator whose repressive values are completely contrary to our own.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="84" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">Given how little we know about what transpired in Helsinki, how can we trust that the President didn't offer, purposely or otherwise, sensitive information that could put our citizens, soldiers, or allies in danger?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="85" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">How can we trust that the President didn't commit the United States to actions or agreements that may be against our Nation's interest?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="86" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">And given that we still don't know the details relating to Russia's involvement in the election of the President, how can we trust that what was discussed between President Trump and his admitted supporter, Vladimir Putin, didn't compromise the President's ability to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against our enemies?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="87" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">These are basic questions that are absolutely critical to our understanding of the administration's policies toward Russia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="88" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">We have an obligation as the committee of jurisdiction over foreign affairs to conduct proper oversight of the administration's actions and policies vis-a-vis Russia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="89" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">I can't imagine what reason my colleagues could possibly use to justify their unwillingness to support this resolution. All it does is ask for documents--documents that will shed light into this important meeting between President Trump and President Putin, and nothing more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="90" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">This is a basic function of our committee that we should exercise without hesitation and because it is our obligation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="91" speaker="Mr. Cicilline">So I ask my colleagues to join me in support of this very well-written resolution of inquiry so that we can get to the bottom of this and really provide transparency to the American people so we can really understand what happened during this very consequential meeting and what are the implications for the United States' national security and our role in the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="92" speaker="Mr. Cicilline"> And with that, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="93" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Any other members seek recognition? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Boyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="94" speaker="Mr. Boyle"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Boyle</speaker> <paragraph paraId="95" speaker="Mr. Boyle">Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and I am pleased to have the opportunity to debate my resolution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="96" speaker="Mr. Boyle">It is now 2 months after the Helsinki Summit and we still don't know what was said in the private meeting.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="97" speaker="Mr. Boyle">The President has not told the American people what he discussed nor has any administration official come before the committee in an open or even a closed setting to brief us on the important foreign policy matters that were addressed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="98" speaker="Mr. Boyle">What we do know is what Donald Trump announced directly following the unprecedented and puzzling one-on-one sit down.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="99" speaker="Mr. Boyle">He sowed seeds of doubt regarding the unwavering conclusion of our intelligence community that Russia interfered in our election to the benefit of Mr. Trump and that Putin used the meeting as a propaganda boost--or propaganda to boost his stature as a check on American leadership.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="100" speaker="Mr. Boyle">And we know what else Russia has been up to since. Our national security agencies have confirmed Russia is still working to attack the upcoming 2018 elections.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="101" speaker="Mr. Boyle">Russia continues to prop up the murderous Assad regime and occupy eastern Ukraine. All of this context fuels important questions regarding the secrecy of this meeting and begs for transparency and congressional oversight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="102" speaker="Mr. Boyle">I introduced this resolution in July following the President's damaging and bizarre remarks at the press conference with Putin following the private sit down where the President met with Putin without any staff or advisors in the room.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="103" speaker="Mr. Boyle">This meeting could have profound foreign policy implications and the President has already built a track record of giving away concessions with nothing in return.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="104" speaker="Mr. Boyle">Did the President promise any concessions on U.S. sanctions on Russia? The U.S. commitment to NATO? The U.S. nonrecognition policy of the Crimea annexation?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="105" speaker="Mr. Boyle">We simply don't know. But we do know that at the press conference President Trump said he ``spent a great deal of time'' talking about the election and that Putin feels strongly about it and has ``an interesting idea.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="106" speaker="Mr. Boyle">What does that mean? The President fueled doubt and speculation by refusing to say whether he believed the United States intelligence community or the Russian dictator on the subject of election interference in 2016.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="107" speaker="Mr. Boyle">Trump said that the special counsel's Russia investigation has been a ``disaster for the U.S. and has kept America and Russia separated.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="108" speaker="Mr. Boyle">These comments can be added to a very long list of ways the President has gone out of his way to cozy up to Putin. Now, I wish this resolution weren't necessary. But here we are, 60 days after the Helsinki Summit and we still don't know what President Trump said or committed to.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="109" speaker="Mr. Boyle">We are a co-equal branch of government. Indeed, in the Constitution, we are the first Article. The executive is the second.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="110" speaker="Mr. Boyle">It is time that we take off our red hat or our blue hat and put on our red, white, and blue hat. As fellow Americans and as Members of Congress, we have a responsibility to do our jobs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="111" speaker="Mr. Boyle">Let's get answers. Let's pass positively this resolution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="112" speaker="Mr. Boyle"> Thank you, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="113" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="114" speaker="Chairman Royce"> We go to Lois Frankel of Florida. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Frankel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="115" speaker="Ms. Frankel">Thank you, Mr. Chair, and I urge support of this important resolution by my colleague, Representative Boyle, that directs the Trump administration to send the House copies of all documents and communications between Trump and Putin during the Helsinki Summit.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="116" speaker="Ms. Frankel">The American people deserve to know the truth of what was discussed and I want to say with emphasis Congress has the oversight and authority, duty, to demand this information and it is critical to national security that this Congress not be just a lackey to the executive branch.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="117" speaker="Ms. Frankel">And yet, the administration has failed to provide any information to come before this committee, as mentioned by my colleagues, and Americans are worried. They are in fear.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="118" speaker="Ms. Frankel">Why is that? As a candidate, now President, Donald Trump refuses to say anything negative about Vladimir Putin. He actually shows admiration for a man who murders his political opponents, meddles in Western democratic elections, suppresses human rights, illegally annexes foreign territory, supports the murderous Assad regime in Syria, and more.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="119" speaker="Ms. Frankel">And right before the Helsinki Summit, President Trump embarrassed our country at NATO, labeling our European allies as foes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="120" speaker="Ms. Frankel">Then standing at Putin's side in Finland he parroted Russian propaganda and repeated Putin's lies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="121" speaker="Ms. Frankel">When asked directly if he believed Russia interfered in our 2016 elections, he said he didn't see any reason why.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="122" speaker="Ms. Frankel">I'll tell you why or what he's ignoring. Number one, our own intelligence community unanimously concluded Russia has meddled in our elections. Number two, the Department of Justice has indicted 25 Russian nationals responsible for the meddling. And number three, Russia has a long proven history of assaulting Western democracies and using cyber attacks, disinformation, and support for nationalist political groups.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="123" speaker="Ms. Frankel">Now, here's the thing. We don't have a clue what was discussed with the two--in the 2-hour-long private meeting between Trump and Putin--what promises were made, whether they talked about sanctions, what about our election.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="124" speaker="Ms. Frankel">We have no answers and the cloud of secrecy is disturbing. We are in fear. It's been reported that they talked about holding a referendum in eastern Ukraine, Iran's presence in Syria, recognition of Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, and the future of our nuclear arsenals, and we know Trump himself said it was a wonderful offer when Putin suggested Russia's interrogators question American citizens, including a former U.S. Ambassador to Russia.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="125" speaker="Ms. Frankel">Is it possible that the President jeopardized our national security when he was alone in the room with Putin? But without these documents, we may never know.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="126" speaker="Ms. Frankel">And I just want to conclude by repeating that Congress has the authority and the oversight duty to demand this information that is critical to our national security.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="127" speaker="Ms. Frankel">I urge we use this responsibility and adopt this resolution.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="128" speaker="Ms. Frankel"> I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="129" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Do any other members seek recognition? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Meeks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="130" speaker="Mr. Meeks"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Meeks</speaker> <paragraph paraId="131" speaker="Mr. Meeks">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="132" speaker="Mr. Meeks">The camera of history is rolling. We do not live in a time where Congress can just sit back. In fact, we live in extraordinary times.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="133" speaker="Mr. Meeks">We cannot fool ourselves and say this is ordinary times because it's not, and history is looking to see what is the United States House of Representatives--what is the Congress going to do to make sure it is utilizing its oversight power of the executive branch--an equal branch of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="134" speaker="Mr. Meeks">And so we cannot pretend that this is a normal circumstance. In fact, a number of my Republican colleagues, especially those that ran for President--not Gregory Meeks-- warned us about some of this back during the campaign during that time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="135" speaker="Mr. Meeks">I'd just refer individuals to the comments of Mr. Romney, who's running for United States Senate now; Mr. Cruz, who is, you know, during that primary period of time; Mr. Rubio, who also had comments about the President at that time, of which I continue to articulate and utilize.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="136" speaker="Mr. Meeks">So they had some clues that this was not going to be an ordinary circumstance if Mr. Trump was elected, and that's why they said the things that they said during that campaign.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="137" speaker="Mr. Meeks">And so what has played out is what we have seen to take place at the Helsinki Summit, which remains astonishing because for the first time a U.S. President sat in front of the world stage to undermine their own Department of Justice, their own intelligence community, and invited a foreign adversary to do the same.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="138" speaker="Mr. Meeks">Without question, this is a troubling moment in our Nation's history. When given a chance to forcefully denounce Russia's interference in our elections, President Trump instead parroted Russia's propaganda.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="139" speaker="Mr. Meeks">Even the administration's latest Executive order sanctioning foreign interference in our elections fails to mention Russia by name.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="140" speaker="Mr. Meeks">This committee's request for documents, records, communications, and even the U.S. translator's notes constitutes not only a moral obligation but an execution of our constitutionally-enshrined right to check and balance the executive branch of government.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="141" speaker="Mr. Meeks">No other vibrant democracy would accept a meeting between its head of state and a former KGB agent whose primary currency is half truths and disinformation and is committed to stirring up discord and division.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="142" speaker="Mr. Meeks">We need accountability and we need it today. Unfortunately, we do not trust the administration not to give away key concessions on issues like Crimea, Ukraine, the nuclear nonproliferation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="143" speaker="Mr. Meeks">It's unprecedented for staff, his advisors, and technical experts to be excluded from discussions with far-reaching implications for not only the United States but the entire global community.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="144" speaker="Mr. Meeks">It is hyperbolic to say Mr. Trump's secretive meeting undermines our national security and aggregates this chamber's ability to perform effective oversight.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="145" speaker="Mr. Meeks">As public stewards dedicated to transparency and the rule of law, we just keep the executive accountable. It is time for all Members of Congress to put their affiliation aside and come together as Americans to address this blatant breach of trust.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="146" speaker="Mr. Meeks">As the biblical maxim says, a little yeast works through the whole batch of dough. The yeast of secrecy and unaccountability, if left unchecked, will undermine the very foundations of our democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="147" speaker="Mr. Meeks">The actions of this President is just puzzling. I would have hoped that if he did then these transcripts would show that he was talking to the Russians, and should have been, about them being complicit with Syria, for example, in utilizing chemical weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="148" speaker="Mr. Meeks">He pulled out of an agreement that all had agreed with with reference to nuclear weapons. But was there any--with Iran--but was there any conversation in that regard and what is Russia's role?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="149" speaker="Mr. Meeks">It seems to me that the American people and all of us here in Congress should know. So I would hope that my--our Republican colleagues and our public oaths require no demand-- I'll note they demand that we examine the Helsinki events closely and if not this body, the American people will regret not doing so and history will so record it, and I thank Mr. Boyle for his amendment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="150" speaker="Mr. Meeks"> And I yield back the balance of my time. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="151" speaker="Chairman Royce">Other members seeking recognition?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="152" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Congresswoman Norma Torres. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Torres</speaker> <paragraph paraId="153" speaker="Ms. Torres">Thank you, Chairman Royce.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="154" speaker="Ms. Torres">H.R. 1017 is an important measure and I thank my colleague, Congressman Boyle, for introducing it, and I also want to thank Chairman Royce and Ranking Member Engel for bringing it before this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="155" speaker="Ms. Torres">H.R. 1017 would force the administration to turn over documents related to the July 16 meeting that took place between President Trump and Vladimir Putin in Helsinki.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="156" speaker="Ms. Torres">As I recall, Democrats were not the only ones with very serious questions about that meeting or concerns. As I recall, many of my Republican colleagues were shocked at the fact that President Trump would meet with Putin with no staff and shocked by the bizarre spectacle of a joint conference in which President Trump treated Putin like a friend, not the adversary that he is.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="157" speaker="Ms. Torres">He is not our friend, and let us be clear about that. Russia is not our ally. As we discussed in this morning's hearing, Russia is a subject to multiple U.S. sanctions for its many malign activities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="158" speaker="Ms. Torres">The United States has sanctioned Russia for corruption, for interfering in our elections, for invading Crimea, for using chemical weapons to poison a former spy in the U.K.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="159" speaker="Ms. Torres">And I won't go into the long and sordid history of President Trump's relationship with Russia. I won't go into the many examples of President Trump's campaign officials' ties to Russia or the administration officials' ties to Russia in general.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="160" speaker="Ms. Torres">There is an ongoing investigation and we must allow that investigation to run its course. But I will say that there are some serious questions about the Helsinki meeting and the American people deserve to know.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="161" speaker="Ms. Torres">I hope that today that we can rise above party politics and bring some much needed transparency to this disturbing episode.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="162" speaker="Ms. Torres"> Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="163" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="164" speaker="Chairman Royce">Do any other members seek recognition?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="165" speaker="Chairman Royce">Seeing no further requests for recognition to speak, the question occurs on the pending motion of the Chair to report the resolution adversely.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="166" speaker="Chairman Royce">The Chair orders a recorded vote, as I stated at the outset, to give all our members a fair opportunity to participate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="167" speaker="Chairman Royce">We are going to take a brief recess and then we reconvene to vote at 1:50.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="168" speaker="Chairman Royce">The committee stands in recess.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="169" speaker="Chairman Royce"> [Recess.] </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="170" speaker="Chairman Royce">Okay. This committee will come back to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="171" speaker="Chairman Royce"> When we recessed, we had concluded debate---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Deutch</speaker> <paragraph paraId="172" speaker="Mr. Deutch">Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="173" speaker="Mr. Deutch"> Mr. Chairman, move to strike the last word. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="174" speaker="Chairman Royce"> The gentleman is recognized. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Deutch</speaker> <paragraph paraId="175" speaker="Mr. Deutch">Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="176" speaker="Mr. Deutch">Mr. Chairman, the legendary journalist, Bob Woodward, released a book with disturbing details about what's going on in the White House.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="177" speaker="Mr. Deutch">White House Chief of Staff General Kelly reportedly said, ``President Trump has gone off the rails. We are in Crazy Town. I don't even know why any of us are here.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="178" speaker="Mr. Deutch">And General Kelly denied some of the comments attributed to him and Woodward is standing by his reporting. Either way, the question it raises is a good one.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="179" speaker="Mr. Deutch">Why are any of us here? Why are any of us up here on this dais? Are we taking our duty to our constituents seriously? Are we living up to Article One of the Constitution? This is the people's House.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="180" speaker="Mr. Deutch">We are the American people's check on power, check on the administration, their oversight of the White House.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="181" speaker="Mr. Deutch">Are we going to take that job seriously? In July, I am sure many of you were as dumbfounded as I was when we saw the President of the United States stand side by side with Russian President Vladimir Putin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="182" speaker="Mr. Deutch">He undermined the conclusions of American intelligence agencies--the agencies made up of hardworking patriotic Americans who sacrificed so much and go out into the most dangerous situations to gather information to keep our country safe.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="183" speaker="Mr. Deutch">The conclusions in their report have been publicly available since January 2017. President Trump pretended they didn't exist. He ignored the American lives that were on the line to create it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="184" speaker="Mr. Deutch">In fact, there are rumors that he considered Putin's request to allow questioning of some of those very U.S. officials. But once again, we don't know where the truth lies because the only people in the room were Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="185" speaker="Mr. Deutch">I don't know about you--that's not what I expect of my President. I expect strength in the face of Russian aggression.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="186" speaker="Mr. Deutch">I don't expect our President to blame America when Russia invaded its neighbors, when it used nerve gas against agents in Britain, when it attacked the foundation of our democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="187" speaker="Mr. Deutch">If history teaches anything, it teaches that simpleminded appeasement or wishful thinking about our adversaries is folly. It means the betrayal of our past, the squandering of our freedom.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="188" speaker="Mr. Deutch">That's how President Reagan said it in 1983. That is a statement with principles at its foundation and our dearest American values at its core.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="189" speaker="Mr. Deutch">You won't hear anything like that coming out of this President's mouth. We cannot be complicit in Donald Trump's abandonment of the principals that used to guide us and we have a lot of work to do to restore American values.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="190" speaker="Mr. Deutch">That's the answer to the question why are we even here. I urge my colleagues who have now returned to this hearing room to oppose the motion to report the resolution adversely so that we can move forward with Mr. Boyle's resolution and advance this committee's responsibility to protect our democracy by pursuing the truth.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="191" speaker="Mr. Deutch"> And I am glad to yield to my friend, Mr. Connolly. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="192" speaker="Mr. Connolly">I thank my friend and I thank him for his eloquence and for setting the parameters of what ought to be a fruitful discussion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="193" speaker="Mr. Connolly">I plead with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle. This committee has by and large seen and heard no evil when it comes to this President, even as he talks down alliances, even as he caters and panders to Vladimir Putin at the summit, even when he trashes our allies in the G7, even when he rips up agreements that disrupts long-term friendships and relationships, even when he deplores the EU and says that NATO, our longest alliance that worked so well and still does, is obsolete.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="194" speaker="Mr. Connolly">Is there any line he can cross that might merit your ire? This resolution, allowed to come to the floor without a recommendation, would be something then the House of Representatives--the people's body--could debate, and fruitfully so.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="195" speaker="Mr. Connolly">Or are we today once again simply going to vote along party lines to protect and defend the indefensible in foreign policy and once again shirk our duty as the committee of jurisdiction and cognizance to protect the foreign interests of the United States of America, even when that means we cross the executive?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="196" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> I hope we think long and hard about our action today and I thank Mr. Boyle for his leadership on this resolution and my friend from Florida for yielding. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Deutch</speaker> <paragraph paraId="197" speaker="Mr. Deutch"> Thank you, and Mr. Chairman---- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="198" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="199" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Mr. Deutch [continuing]. I appreciate it. I yield back the balance of my time. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="200" speaker="Chairman Royce">All right.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="201" speaker="Chairman Royce">The pending question is on the motion to report House Resolution 1017 adversely. In other words, if you share my opposition to the resolution, you would vote aye.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="202" speaker="Chairman Royce"> The clerk will call the roll. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="203" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> Would the chair entertain a parliamentary inquiry first? </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="204" speaker="Chairman Royce"> I will entertain that inquiry. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="205" speaker="Mr. Connolly">I thank the chair.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="206" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> Just a couple of parliamentary inquiries. Is the motion---- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="207" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Will the gentleman state his inquiry? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="208" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> Yes. I am going to ask if the motion is amendable. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="209" speaker="Chairman Royce"> It is not at this point. We could consider an alternative motion only if this motion was defeated. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="210" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> Because I have---- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="211" speaker="Chairman Royce">The motion before us----</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="212" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Mr. Connolly [continuing]. I have an itsy bitsy change in the adverb from adversely to favorably. [Laughter.] </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="213" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Well--well, we could--we could consider that if this motion fails. But this is the motion before us, </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="214" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> I thank the chair. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="215" speaker="Chairman Royce">All right. Well, thank you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="216" speaker="Chairman Royce"> So the pending question--we will ask the clerk to call the roll. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Marter</speaker> <paragraph paraId="217" speaker="Ms. Marter"> Mr. Chairman. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="218" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Marter</speaker> <paragraph paraId="219" speaker="Ms. Marter"> The chairman votes aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="220" speaker="Mr. Smith"> </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Smith</speaker> <paragraph paraId="221" speaker="Mr. Smith"> Aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Marter</speaker> <paragraph paraId="222" speaker="Ms. Marter">Mr. Smith votes aye.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="223" speaker="Ms. Marter">Ms. Ros-Lehtinen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="224" speaker="Ms. Marter"> Ms. Ros-Lehtinen. Aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Marter</speaker> <paragraph paraId="225" speaker="Ms. Marter"> Ms. Ros-Lehtinen votes aye. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rohrabacher</speaker> <paragraph paraId="226" Connolly"> I just have a UC request to enter something into the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="358" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Without--well, let--state the nature of your UC request. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="359" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> I have a series of 20 different quotes from Members of Congress with respect to the Helsinki performance. I was simply asking unanimous consent they be entered into the record. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="360" speaker="Chairman Royce"> Without objection. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Cicilline</speaker> <paragraph paraId="361" speaker="Mr. Cicilline"> May I ask--I am sorry, Mr. Chairman. May I ask that those--before I decide whether to object that Mr. Connolly read those statements? [Laughter.] </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="362" speaker="Chairman Royce">I think there will be objection at that point. [Laughter.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="363" speaker="Chairman Royce"> So might I suggest that---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Connolly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="364" speaker="Mr. Connolly">I would ask my friend from Rhode Island to perhaps withdraw his request. [Laughter.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="365" speaker="Mr. Connolly"> I thank the chair. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="366" speaker="Chairman Royce">Very good. I am trying to be helpful here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="367" speaker="Chairman Royce">That concludes our business. Without objection, the committee is adjourned.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="368" speaker="Chairman Royce">[Whereupon, at 2:05 p.m., the committee was adjourned.]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="369" speaker="Chairman Royce">----------</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="370" speaker="Chairman Royce">Material Submitted for the Record Material submitted for the record by the Honorable Gerald E.
